headline.main: Though the Body's Still Warm, The Cold War Is Collectible

results.snippet: 1991: The Cold War ends. A new collecting opportunity begins. History take note: Norman Brosterman, lone devotee of the Techno-Future, was there.   At the "Modernism" antiques show in Manhattan last fall, Mr. Brosterman showed the world the meaning...
results.lead_paragraph: 1991: The Cold War ends. A new collecting opportunity begins. History take note: Norman Brosterman, lone devotee of the Techno-Future, was there. At the "Modernism" antiques show in Manhattan last fall, Mr. Brosterman showed the world the meaning of modernism, as defined by Norman Brosterman. While other dealers gloated over their Stickley and Art Nouveau, Mr. Brosterman showed up with paintings of enemy missiles zooming over Washington and mannequins in NASA helmets and spacesuits decked out for the space race.

headline.main: 5,000 Space Shuttle Jobs to Be Cut In Next Five Years, NASA Reports

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to eliminate 5,000 space shuttle jobs over five years so it can afford such ambitious projects as the building of a lunar base and a flight to Mars.   "All of those things cost money, and...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to eliminate 5,000 space shuttle jobs over five years so it can afford such ambitious projects as the building of a lunar base and a flight to Mars. "All of those things cost money, and there aren't going to be many new bucks for NASA to work with," Robert Crippen, the new director of the Kennedy Space Center here, said Monday in a televised address to workers. "Consequently, we need to be able to reduce programs like the shuttle, but do it safely so that we can do these other exciting things."

headline.main: Filming Life, He Found His Own

results.snippet: "Thirty-five Up," the latest installment in the documentary series about the lives of 14 Britons, is the culmination of 28 years' work, and as far as I know is the longest-running project in the history of film. It started in 1964 with "7 Up," a...
results.lead_paragraph: "Thirty-five Up," the latest installment in the documentary series about the lives of 14 Britons, is the culmination of 28 years' work, and as far as I know is the longest-running project in the history of film. It started in 1964 with "7 Up," a documentary produced by Granada Television that looked at Britain through the eyes of these individuals as 7-year-olds. I was 22, had just left Cambridge University with a law degree and had been hired to find the children from as diverse backgrounds as possible and, with the director Paul Almond, to get their opinions on money, love, God, sex, race, school and one another. We also wanted to know what they had in mind for their futures. These were the politicians, managers, union leaders and parents of the year 2000, so what kind of England could we look forward to? We used the Jesuit idea "give me a child until he is 7 and I will show you the man," but, frankly, our underlying concept was political. Granada was a left-wing company, and in the heady days of 1964 when England was the pop-cultural center of the world, we wanted to see whether the dynamics that gave fame and fortune to the Beatles, the Stones and other icons had permeated our class system. Did everybody have a fair chance, or did the accident of birth bring power, wealth and success? Were children made into winners or losers by class divisions, or was the old order changing forever?

headline.main: Happy Birthday, HAL; What Went Wrong?

results.snippet: HAL: Good afternoon, Gent-le-men. I am a HAL 9000 computer. I became operational at the H.A.L. labs in Urbana, Ill., on the 12th of January, 1992. My instructor was Mr. Langley and he taught me to sing a song. If you'd like to hear it, I can sing...
results.lead_paragraph: HAL: Good afternoon, Gent-le-men. I am a HAL 9000 computer. I became operational at the H.A.L. labs in Urbana, Ill., on the 12th of January, 1992. My instructor was Mr. Langley and he taught me to sing a song. If you'd like to hear it, I can sing it for you. Astronaut: Yes. I'd like to hear it, HAL. Sing it for me. HAL: It's called "Daisy" . . .

headline.main: International Crew Set For Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: THE space shuttle Discovery is poised to carry an international crew into orbit on a mission that will simulate many of the planned activities aboard Space Station Freedom.   The Discovery is to be launched tomorrow with a crew of seven and a...
results.lead_paragraph: THE space shuttle Discovery is poised to carry an international crew into orbit on a mission that will simulate many of the planned activities aboard Space Station Freedom. The Discovery is to be launched tomorrow with a crew of seven and a pressurized laboratory in its cargo bay. During the seven-day flight, the crew will conduct medical and scientific experiments that depend upon escaping the influences of gravity.

headline.main: Astronauts From 3 Countries Ride Shuttle Into Orbit

results.snippet: Seven astronauts from three countries sailed flawlessly into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Discovery and began a busy week of medical and scientific experiments.   The Discovery bolted from the Earth on a column of cream-colored smoke at...
results.lead_paragraph: Seven astronauts from three countries sailed flawlessly into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Discovery and began a busy week of medical and scientific experiments. The Discovery bolted from the Earth on a column of cream-colored smoke at 9:52 A.M. The flight was delayed for an hour because of concerns about weather, an errant warning about a problem with a fuel cell and remote sensor readings indicating a potential problem with lightning.

headline.main: 4 Space Veterans and 3 Novices Make Trip

results.snippet: Col. Ronald J. Grabe  Mission Commander    Colonel Grabe, a 46-year-old Air Force pilot and veteran of two shuttle flights, made his first trip into space seven years ago.
results.lead_paragraph: Col. Ronald J. Grabe Mission Commander Colonel Grabe, a 46-year-old Air Force pilot and veteran of two shuttle flights, made his first trip into space seven years ago.

headline.main: Wall Street; Hot Times for a Hybrid

results.snippet: Convertible subordinated debentures. No other phrase seems to capture quite so perfectly the essence of Wall Street jargon. Indeed, comedians poking fun at the financial world have long known that they could simply pronounce that term, in slowly...
results.lead_paragraph: Convertible subordinated debentures. No other phrase seems to capture quite so perfectly the essence of Wall Street jargon. Indeed, comedians poking fun at the financial world have long known that they could simply pronounce that term, in slowly rounded tones, and rest their case. Well, it looks as if Wall Street will get the last laugh. With yields at rock-bottom levels and with stocks soaring into regions that only an astronaut could love, some savvy investors are taking a fresh look at these obscure securities. The reason lies in the neat parlor trick they perform: in a soaring stock market, they act like a stock, but when stocks slump, they act like a bond.

results.snippet: Space officials today extended the week-long flight of the space shuttle Discovery by a day to gather more scientific data, a rare occurrence in the 11-year shuttle program.   Scientists welcomed an extra day to give experimental mercury iodide...
results.lead_paragraph: Space officials today extended the week-long flight of the space shuttle Discovery by a day to gather more scientific data, a rare occurrence in the 11-year shuttle program. Scientists welcomed an extra day to give experimental mercury iodide crystals more time to grow. The shuttle is now scheduled to return on Thursday at Edwards Air Force Base in California.

headline.main: Around the World With Balloon And Gizmos

results.snippet: FOR more than two centuries aeronauts have dreamed of circumnavigating the world in a balloon, the last great aeronautical challenge remaining to be conquered. All the adventurers who previously attempted the daunting 22,000-mile voyage have...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR more than two centuries aeronauts have dreamed of circumnavigating the world in a balloon, the last great aeronautical challenge remaining to be conquered. All the adventurers who previously attempted the daunting 22,000-mile voyage have failed, but this week an American balloon ace, a seasoned aeronautical mechanic and a senior Russian astronaut are completing preparations for the launching of Earthwinds, the most complex and advanced balloon ever built. If all goes well in the next few days here, the huge craft, carrying American and Russian scientific experiments as well as the three crew members, will ascend on Thursday or Friday from its berth at the Loral Defense Systems Air Dock, a gigantic hangar built in 1929 to accommodate the largest dirigibles ever built in America, the ill-fated Akron and Macon. The Earthwinds balloon is supposed to rise slowly to an altitude of about 35,000 feet, slip into the eastward-flowing jet stream, and complete its trip around the world in something under two weeks.

headline.main: Weather Looking Good for Round-the-World Balloon Flight

results.snippet: As helium gas screamed from a tank truck into a huge plastic gas bag yesterday, final preparations began for the launching of Earthwinds, a balloon whose three-member crew hopes to be the first to circumnavigate the world in a single balloon...
results.lead_paragraph: As helium gas screamed from a tank truck into a huge plastic gas bag yesterday, final preparations began for the launching of Earthwinds, a balloon whose three-member crew hopes to be the first to circumnavigate the world in a single balloon flight. Larry Newman of Scottsdale, Ariz., captain of the Earthwinds, said there was a good chance that weather conditions in Akron, Ohio, would permit the launching of the balloon this weekend to begin its voyage of some 22,000 miles at an altitude of about 35,000 feet.

headline.main: Crises Surmounted, Balloon Ready for Global Trip

results.snippet: For six anxious hours Tuesday night, a platoon of technicians, engineers and master balloonists in Akron, Ohio, wrestled with cables, machinery and tank trucks of helium gas as they inflated Earthwinds, whose crew hopes to be the first in history...
results.lead_paragraph: For six anxious hours Tuesday night, a platoon of technicians, engineers and master balloonists in Akron, Ohio, wrestled with cables, machinery and tank trucks of helium gas as they inflated Earthwinds, whose crew hopes to be the first in history to circle the earth in a balloon. After surmounting several heart-stopping technical crises, the team pronounced the $5 million balloon inflated and nearly ready to begin its perilous voyage.

headline.main: New Michelob Spots Seek Wider Appeal

results.snippet: The night used to belong to Michelob. Now, it is claiming the days.   An advertising campaign created for the struggling Anheuser-Busch brand by its new agency, D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, carries the theme "Some days are better...
results.lead_paragraph: The night used to belong to Michelob. Now, it is claiming the days. An advertising campaign created for the struggling Anheuser-Busch brand by its new agency, D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, carries the theme "Some days are better than others."
